column4: It automatically refreshes every few seconds.  I don't think that nm-applet has a button to do it manually.
Run `iwconfig` at a prompt and check whether the computer has a wireless interface configured.
That comes up good (I think), its assigned to wlan0
Does the  "wlan0" line say something like "IEEE 802.11abgn"?
Okay, that stuff means that the driver for the wifi interface is loaded.
Ask the wifi interface directly for a list of networks.  Run `sudo iwlist scan` at the prompt.
It shows the different ESSID's available in range
Okay, that means that the glitch is in the network manager.
Did it ever work, or has it always been broken?
Check the /etc/network/interfaces file for a mention of wlan0.  Network Manager won't automatically configure most interfaces that have any kind of static configuration.
Can I add "auto wlan0" or something?
No, don't do that.  It is okay for that file to be empty or sparse.
Check the computer for a toggle switch with the wifi logo, or a network logo.
Many laptop computers have a physical switch that disconnects or disables the wifi card.
Have done that several times already. It lights up as active (the wirless) when I turn it to on.
Okay, do a cold restart.  Power off, let it sit, and power on.
